utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: What time?

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Why so late?

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: Make-up test in social studies.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Did you invite Shelby for Saturday?

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Do you want me to call her?

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: Yeah, that'd be great. You calling a 12-year-old girl for a sleepover.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: It'll be fine.

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: Make you a deal. I'll call a friend when you call a friend.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: It's your birthday. Do what you want.

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: Thank you. Bye.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Bye.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: What did you forget?

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: Nothing.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Then why'd you come back?

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: 'Cause I live here.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Come on, Samantha, you're gonna be late for school.

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: What are you talking about? It's 4:30.

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: Are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: I, uh… Tired, I guess.

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: What's wrong?

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: I don't know.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Great. That's all I need to know. You're late! Okay, bye. 37-year-old male with recurring blackouts.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tell him to switch from tequila to bourbon. Worked for me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The three doctors he's already seen already ruled out drugs and alcohol.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, then it's epilepsy. Tell him to buy a hockey helmet —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: EEG's clean. So is the CT.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Relax. Just because you got approved by an adoption agency doesn't mean you'll get approved by the birth mother. You're a single mom. That puts you somewhere below couples acquitted in day care scandals.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You're welcome, Dr. House. It is an interesting case.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What time are you seeing the mom?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Are you having your guy follow me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I just trashed your social value as a mother, and all I got was a little sarcasm. It means you don't feel the need to defend yourself, which means you're not worried about getting a kid, which means you've already got one.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We're meeting at 11:00. She's due to deliver a baby girl in two weeks.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm sure the mom'll be thrilled to hand her crack baby off to a doctor.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She's not a crack baby.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, mother's perfectly healthy. She just had to give up the baby in order to continue her work on the human genome.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She confessed to some past meth use.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What they don't confess to is almost always more interesting. This is a mistake.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Because a kid you don't know may have some problems you don't know about that she may have passed on to a kid?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because you're a control seeking narcissist. Which is fine, good even, in some jobs. But you're not equipped to handle a real kid, never mind a factory second. Where are you meeting her?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: In a little place called "follow me and your urologist will be buying himself a new yacht."

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They explained the returns policy, right? It's worse than video games.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'm not changing my mind.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Could be post concussion syndrome.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not without a pre-concussion. Pick a number.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: For what?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cuddy pool. She got the nod. Little tweaker's due in 14 days.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: That's great news… I think.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's good news. The great news is she insisted that she's not gonna change her mind, which means she's actually thought about changing her mind, which means she's not sure she's ready to be a mom, which means she's not ready to be a mom, which means she's gonna change her mind. The only question is when. $100 buy in. Less than seven means the next seven days.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But she's been dying for a kid for three years. No way she's gonna back out now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not one of the options.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Mini strokes can cause blackouts and memory loss.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Nine hours is a lot of time to be out for a mini stroke.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And there'd be residual damage on the CT.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Guy works at home as a consumer product tester. He could've been exposed to a toxin that caused short-term memory loss. Wouldn't show up on imaging.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Cavernous sinus thrombosis could cause absence seizures and memory loss. I'll take 7 to 14.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We have a player.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You just said it was great news. Now you want to bet against her?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: It's only great news if she wants it to be great news. House knows her better than any of us. I'd rather use a pseudonym.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good thinking. I say she's gonna meet the mom and bolt. I'm going for the early fold. Check his home for toxins and his sinuses for thrombosises.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Maybe he ODed on caffeine.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Apparently he didn't drink the coffee, just smelled it.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Wow. Did they just move here?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Six years ago.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: This is no way to raise a kid.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He's a single dad. I'm sure he's doing his best.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Which is why single people shouldn't have kids.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You got a problem with what Cuddy's doing? You think single mothers can't —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I think the traditional family is a fraud. Even married moms are single moms. Daddy just pays some bills and reads just enough bedtime stories to not kill himself out of guilt.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: My dad was great. After my mom died —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He might be the exception. On the other hand, you are fairly screwed up.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No booze, no meds, no drugs.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: And no view. Building's half-empty. He'd rather have a view of the turnpike than the park.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Park views are probably 50% more. You're the surprised the guy's a pragmatist after looking at this place?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Guy's not a pragmatist. He's a flagellant.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Ump. Looks like mold.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Mom would've cleaned better.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Exposure to certain types of mold can cause short-term memory loss. We're testing both of you.

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: I feel fine.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I'm sure you are. We're just being cautious. So where do you guys go other than home and school?

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: Nowhere. Dad works at home, and I go to school.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: What about sports, friends, travel?

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: Like I said, dad works at home, and I go to school.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Must be hard not having your mom around, huh?

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: I was only four when the accident happened.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Still, I'm sure you both miss her sometimes.

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: Not really.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You're strong.

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: No, I just don't get what the big deal about death is, you know?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How is she?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Physically, she's fine. Mentally, she's weird.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm sure she's just freaked out about her dad. Mr. Harmon? Mr. Harmon.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: I have an appointment. I have to go.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We haven't finished with your treatment. We're still waiting on some test results.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: I have an appointment.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sorry, you're gonna have to reschedule.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: I really have to go.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Mr. Harmon, do you know where you are?

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Why are you trying to stop me?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Look at his eyes.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Is he having a seizure?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His pupils are responsive. I think he's… asleep.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He was just asleep. Means no memory loss. And sleepwalking doesn't kill. Unless he walks out a window.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sleepwalking's not a diagnosis. It's a symptom. As long as we can't figure out why —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Stress-induced insomnia. Lots of people sleepwalk.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not in the middle of the day before they've even put their head on a pillow.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Could be some sort of narcolepsy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which is caused by…

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: There's usually genetic history.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: If you know the answer, can you tell us the answer?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't know the answer. Which brings us back to — or?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Some sort of environmental trigger.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which means?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It's a toxin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So we are?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Being lead down an annoying path.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I honestly don't know where this is going. Just following the clues.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We're right back where we started. The mold we found doesn't cause these symptoms. And there's nothing else at his home.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: And you're obnoxious. He never goes anywhere else.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which we know because?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Because he says so. Because his daughter says so. Because they have no reason to lie.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which proves he never goes anywhere else… when… he's…

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Conscious.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, my God, you're right.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He said he had an appointment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Next time, let him keep it. Send him home. See where his dreams take him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Becca?

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Dr. Cuddy?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Lisa. Nice to meet you.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Oh, you want one?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No thanks.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: I can't stop eating them. I guess it's, like, a craving. I must have, like, a dozen a day. Oh, and this is decaf.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How have you been feeling?

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Oh, you know, tired, fat, nervous.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Is there, um, anything you want to ask me?

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Uh, yeah, actually, I just have one question. Um, what are you gonna call her?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Ah, I'm not sure. It's all been rather sudden, you know? I like Joy. But as I said, I haven't really decided yet.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Well, is there anything you want to ask me? It's okay.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The agency web site is filled with prospective parents. Their photos, their biographies. There's so many wonderful people out there. Wonderful couples.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Why did I choose a single mom? My grandmother was married for 37 years to a man that treated her like garbage. And my mom would've stayed married to my loser dad that long, but he dumped her. You know, I never understood how you could fall for the same crap as your mother. Then I met Tony. When I read your bio, a doctor, a head of a hospital, I saw your picture… I don't want her raised by a loser.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How long have you had that rash?

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: I don't know. A few days?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Have you had any joint pain?

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Yeah, I'm pregnant. All my joints hurt.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: They shouldn't all hurt. Have you been using?

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Not in seven months. Not since I found out I was pregnant.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That needs to be checked out.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You sure you don't want children?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You know, just because we're stuck here and I'm lying down doesn't mean we need to get deep.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You're afraid you'll make the same mistake you made with your wife. Get caught taking some other kid to a ball game.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I like my life as it is.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Alpha waves increasing.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Any change in demeanor?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No, nothing. He just got up.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Maybe it's a result of the blood pressure change. Delta waves, out of nowhere. He's now asleep. Brain's supposed to turn off motor function.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: If the brain was doing what it was supposed to be doing, we wouldn't be here. He's leaving. Come on.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She's 38 weeks. You think it's fifth disease?

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: What's that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It's a viral infection. It can infect the fetus.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Usually in the first 20 weeks of pregnancy, and in women who have trouble with their immune system.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: History of drug use could've compromised her immune system.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: I told you I haven't used anything in seven months.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It does look more like a heat rash to me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yes, well, maybe we want to look at the actual blood tests.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: She works for you?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Everybody here works for you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: When this happens for real, are you okay to deliver here?

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Yeah, sure.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Blood work's normal.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Test it again.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Tested it twice. I'll get you some topical cream for that rash.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'm admitting her.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There's nothing wrong with her.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: There are dozens of other things this rash could indicate. I want a full fetal work up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're losing it. That's what happens when you have kids. Ceaseless crying and nagging leads to irrational fears. It's impressive that you didn't wait for the actual crying and nagging.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She had a lace pattern rash, joint pain, and a history of drug abuse. You would've done exactly the same thing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh-huh. And I'd be an excellent father.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Hey! What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Baby barf. Maternity ward was handing out free samples.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well played, sir. You leave me no choice but to change. My clothes, not my mind.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's exactly my point. It's not gonna be me and a cup. It's gonna be eight times a day. If you can't handle wearing that stain, you can't handle a baby.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why do you even care? It's not like I'm ever gonna ask you to babysit.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm a humanitarian.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We should stop him.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: The whole point was to —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Let him plow into some innocent bystander?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: His legs are working. Obviously, his eyes are working too.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: His reaction time could be slower.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He's stopping.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Yeah, I see. He's having sleep sex.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Maybe. Pull up to her.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: What'd that guy want?

utterance.speaker: Sadie
utterance.content: Piss off.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Go after him. She's not a hooker.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: How do you know?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Do you want me to describe the clues, or do you want to stop him before he finishes off the drugs he just bought?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Apparently, Rip's a coke fiend.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So Sleeping Beauty has a Jones for Snow White.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Coke explains the narcolepsy. Narcolepsy explains the sleepwalking.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But it doesn't explain the rip in the space-time continuum. Coke leads to sleepwalking, which leads to coke, which leads to sleepwalking. What caused the first sleepwalking?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: The coke he took while he was wide-awake.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Says he didn't.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Wouldn't be the first time somebody lied about drug use.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: He has no reason to lie. He knows he's sick. His job doesn't drug test. No relationship. His daughter wouldn't find out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Maybe he just forgot.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Forgot he did cocaine? You're going with forgot over lying?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fits. Cocaine explains the narcolepsy. Narcolepsy explains the sleepwalking. Whatever is in the cocaine other than the cocaine explains the memory loss.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Dealers cut this stuff with all kinds of garbage.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Great, we'll start him on immediate treatment for all kinds of garbage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You can narrow it down in the lab.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Not without a sample.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So get a sample.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You want us to score cocaine from a drug dealer?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's exciting.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It's a felony.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's necessary.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There she is. Amniotic fluid looks good. Good fetal movement. Heart's beating nicely.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It looks like pulmonary hypoplasia.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: What's that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The baby's lungs are underdeveloped. She won't be able to breath on her own.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: She might die?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don't know.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If she was born today, she'd be in trouble, but we're not gonna let that happen. We'll put you on magnesium to prevent labor and steroids to grow the lungs. It's a good thing Dr. Cuddy brought you in.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: How do you know what a drug dealer looks like?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I'm not doing drugs, if that's what you're asking. I just noticed that she had cash in her hand. Obviously came from him. Obviously didn't have enough time to perform any other services.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I didn't notice her holding any —

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Mmph. There she is.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Uh, we're not cops. Cops aren't allowed to say that, right?

utterance.speaker: Sadie
utterance.content: Yeah, they can say it. But if you were a cop, you'd know that. What do you want?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I would like to buy some cocaine, please.

utterance.speaker: Sadie
utterance.content: Oh, definitely not a cop.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Wait.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It's good.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Glad you like it, Pablo. Now can we go?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No. You gave us the wrong stuff.

utterance.speaker: Sadie
utterance.content: What are you talking about? You got my best.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I know. I don't want the good "get your new customer hooked" stuff. I want the stepped on "keep the old customer coming back for more" stuff.

utterance.speaker: Sadie
utterance.content: Are you crazy, bitch?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No, I'm a just a bitch who knows what she wants.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Looks like this kid thing is really working out for you. All of the shopping, none of the stretch marks.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Not a good time.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, kid's getting worse. Blessing in disguise. Although a completely predictable one. You take in strays, don't be surprised by the worms.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Still wearing the sweater.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I didn't say you weren't stubborn. I said you weren't maternal.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Thank you. Go away.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're getting crankier.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Baby's sick. Sorry I'm not finding the fun in that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is it really worth it? Just for the pursuit of unconditional love?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Only you could see that as a bad thing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's a fake thing. There's no unconditional love. It's just unconditional need. Don't make this child a victim of your biological clock.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Victim? You think she's better off staying —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes! Because at least she knows she's not qualified for the job.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Let me guess. I'm gonna tell her not to play ball in the house, but she's not gonna listen.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, actually, I was going for "she sneaks her boyfriend in while you're sleeping, and he wants to do it on the desk." And at first she says no, but she has issues with self-esteem.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You know you're gonna pay for that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm paying for it right now. With wisdom.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Get out.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We found lactose. The coke was cut with milk powder.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Makes it nutritious.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Not much of a toxin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It is if he's allergic to milk.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He's not. He has milk in his fridge.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How does he like his coffee?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I don't know. What does that —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What type of cereal's in the cabinet?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Cocoa-something. Why, what does it matter?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He likes his coffee black. Milk's for the kid.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: How can you be sure?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because if he drank the milk, he'd know that he's lactose intolerant. Ask him, then treat him for allergic reaction. If he gets better, we all get to go home early.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Steroids make you more prone to infection. You'll have to stay here for the next two weeks so we can monitor you.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: The baby's lungs, is that because of… the meth?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Could be.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: You must hate me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If you'd done everything right in your life, I wouldn't be getting a baby.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: You're not scared?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I am scared.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: You got, like, this perfect life.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Not yet.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: What's that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Heart rate's climbing.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: What's wrong with her?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It's not the baby. It's you. I need two units of O-negative, stat!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The mother had a stage two placental abruption. She's losing blood.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So deliver the baby.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The lungs are ten weeks premature.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So deliver now, risk the baby. Deliver later, risk the mom. It's not your baby yet. It's not your call.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She'll do whatever I tell her to do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Self-worth issues. That's genetic, you know. You should deliver now.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are you serious?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You're not? You just told me —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The wrong answer. You can give the mom more blood. You can't give the fetus more lungs.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The lungs might work. It's the right decision medically.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And yet you're here.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: To get your opinion, not to get jerked around.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See, this is what's screwed up here. You're not sure that this is the right call, but you are sure that this is what you want to tell her. And that scares you because your motives aren't medical. Some part of you doesn't want this baby, and that part wants to tell her to kill it.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This is an impossible situation. I'm advising her to take the safest route.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right. Doesn't explain why you changed your sweater.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need your advice.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It's not cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wow. Can you remove spleens with your mind too?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're here to talk about Cuddy. The file is a pretext.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why the hell haven't you come to talk to me about Cuddy? I've been doing all sorts of insane stuff.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If she can't handle your insanity, she can't handle a baby.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's exactly my point.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, it isn't. You're feeling threatened because she's going onto high school and leaving you behind to repeat the eighth grade.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She's sleeping with the math teacher to get a diploma.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Adoption is cheating? Are they giving her a fake kid?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's the problem. She gets to have a relationship with a kid, but she can't handle one with an adult. So she's gonna kill it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, it does seem cleaner. I've seen the file. She's making a judgment call.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Decisions are never made in a vacuum.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Just like your decision to make her miserable. You're doing this because we no longer have inkwells and Cuddy doesn't have pigtails.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why do you think I did that?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: How you doing?

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Not sure. Been keeping an eye on the clock like you said. I don't think I lost any time.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: The machinery agrees with you. That means your problems were caused by the coke.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Can't believe I did coke.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You were asleep.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: I chose to do coke.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: In your sleep. You weren't responsible.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Something inside me wanted to do it. Something inside of me didn't think it was wrong.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It's like a dream. We all do stuff in our dreams we wouldn't do when we're awake.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: I don't.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What's that?

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Did I fall asleep and hurt myself? I don't see any cuts.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Because there aren't any. I think… You're sweating blood.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Guy's bleeding out of his pores. What does that tell us? Other than that you don't want to play basketball against him and he's dying?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And neither cocaine or allergies are the answer.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: It's gotta be systemic. Hemorrhagic virus, maybe?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You think it's Ebola? His white blood cell count would be through the roof. It's not an infection.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: DIC?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Coags are normal.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It's cancer. Leukemia explains everything.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: No fever.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: The bleeding.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: No weight loss.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: The rash.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: No headache.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: The fatigue.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Leukemia'd be obvious from the CBC.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Leukemia has false negatives all the time.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So we have four reasons for leukemia, four reasons against.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Only need one against.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, if we had one reason for anything else. Go do a bone marrow biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: What would you do?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I think… I think you should wait.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: But if I wait… I could die.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: There would be more danger for you, but —

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Is this your opinion as a doctor or as a mother?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It's my medical opinion. It's my personal opinion. I don’t —

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: I don't want to wait.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It might only be one week. We will keep you on plasma.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: This is not my baby. I have already sacrificed nine months for this stupid mistake. I don't… I don't want to sacrifice any more.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Becca, you asked my opinion because you wanted to do the right thing. You are giving up this baby because you don't want to make the mistakes your mom made, her mom made. You have a chance to break this cycle, to do something great for this baby.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I need you to hold still.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Wait. Have you been testing any tanning creams or sprays?

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: It's not a tan. Means it's not leukemia.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Chem panel confirms kidney failure, end stage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Got him on dialysis?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: BP's too low.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Too bad. It would've been nice to have more than an hour or two to solve this thing.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Hemachromatosis?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He have tiny testes?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No. Scleroderma.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His skin's darker, not lighter. As much fun as 20 questions tends to be, he's blowing blood out of every orifice, you think it just might be vascular?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Vasculitis?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I had said it might be "vitas gerular," would you have said "Vitas Gerulaitis?" Test him for vasculitis, angio and blood.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Even if we're right, he's gonna need a kidney transplant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Test the daughter.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: She's 12.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Small kidney. It just means he won't pee as much. Great for road trips.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I meant she's a minor and daddy has a conflict, so we're gonna need Cuddy's sign off.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So get it.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: She's… kind of busy.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Clamp. Suction. Entering the abdominal cavity. There's the head.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Got a minute?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Get out of here.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Who's that?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Dr. Gregory House. He's the one you'll be suing when you develop sepsis.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Well, why is he here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Better question is why is she here? You're an administrator. Administrate. I have a patient's daughter needs a guardian ad litem.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That's it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tests are inconclusive. But either way he's gonna need —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House, get out!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This doesn't need you. I do.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Head's out.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Later.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Later's too late.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And there she is.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Come on, cry. Come on. Come on. Joy, cry. Cry, Joy.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Ah. That's the sound we like to hear. Apgar's nine out of ten.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You hear that? You just got your first "A."

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: She's… yours now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mazel Tov. Now it's time to say those magic words you'll be telling her for the rest of her life, “Mommy's gotta go to work.”

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Have the risks of the transplant procedure been explained to you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Damn it. I was hoping you weren't going to ask her that. Of course she knows. Can you just sign the paperwork?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Dr. House explained to you that all surgeries carry risk? You could die.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And if you don't do it, daddy will die.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Stop pressuring her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry. Daddy's perfectly healthy. But we want you to give him a kidney anyway because it'd be cool if he had three.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Shut up. Do you understand the risks of living with one kidney?

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And you still want to proceed with the transplant?

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Okay, go ahead.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'm saying you can proceed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm saying I can't. Whatever he has, she has too. She's sleepwalking.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: If we don't give him a new kidney, he's dead in a week. We have to transplant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When your remote has a dead battery, you don't replace it with another dead battery. Whatever's killing the dad's kidneys is gonna kill the kid's too.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It is possible the sleep issues aren't medically related. Maybe they're both insomniacs due to the turnpike noise. Maybe they both drink too much coffee, maybe —

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: House is right.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: How do you know?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Because the daughter's sweating blood. If they have the same thing, it means there has to be a common cause. Which means it has to be a toxin, infection, or genetic. And since we've ruled out infections and toxins —

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: It narrows it down to any one of a dozen genetic disorders, each of which takes more than a week to run.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Call Foreman. Get to work.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Cuddy is positively aglow. What's your theory? She's only acting happy to make you miserable?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need a genetic disease.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm sure you're carrying a few.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Symptoms are kidney failure, bleeding, and insomnia.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You paid off the pool? Technically, anyone who didn't enter is a winner.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's not over yet. Everyone's happy until they unwrap that pretty present and find they got a wall clock in the shape of Africa.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Adoption's a cheat, remember? There's no real pregnancy, so there's no stranded dopamine receptors, so there's no postpartum depression. Cuddy will be the happiest new mother you've ever seen. I've just given you the answer, haven't I? And now you're going to walk out of here without saying a word.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good news. I know what you have, and you're both gonna be fine.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What? Are you serious?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes and no.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So you do know what they have?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But they aren't gonna be fine?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No idea. They might be.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why the hell would you say they were?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To make them happy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: For two seconds?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Technically, to see if they can be happy. We should've seen a grin, a twinkle, a sigh of relief, something.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: They're sick. They're tired.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They're anhedonic, incapable of experiencing pleasure. Something's bushwhacked their dopamine receptors.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: They're depressed. Mom's dead. Dad's dying. You should know that being bummed isn't necessarily a pathology.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Being bummed doesn't explain their lack of friends or their indifference to each other.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Why their place had no music, no view, no decor.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: But if you can't feel pleasure, what's with the cocaine?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Really? Is that why you do drugs? Because you're happy? Most people do 'em because they want to be happy. His subconscious craved it, needed it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Most common cause of anhedonia is schizophrenia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure, in white folk.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: They're… black?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They're liars. What's your name?

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Jerry Harmon.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your real name. Hosarian? Herzog? H'ali-baba?

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Hammoud. Jamal Hammoud. Changed it when we invaded Iraq the first time. How'd you know?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You and your daughter have Familial Mediterranean Fever. It's a genetic disease contracted by people of Mediterranean descent. Sephardic Jews, Armenians, Arabs. Causes anhedonia, seizures, kidney failure, even lactose intolerance. Symptoms are set off by age and stress. Kid couldn't get happy, but she could get stressed by daddy dying.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: You don't know if we'll get better?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Treatment tends to be hit and miss once you reach the sweating blood stage. Start them on colchicine and melphalan.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His kidneys are fried. If he doesn't have FMF, the colchicine will kill him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Boy, sure hope I'm right.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Mr. Harmon? Mr. Harmon, I need you to open your eyes. Feeling better?

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: How's Samantha?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Healthy enough to toss you a kidney.

utterance.speaker: Samantha
utterance.content: Dad?

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Sammy.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The baby's doing great. I… I can't imagine how hard this must be for you.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: I was —I was stupid and selfish.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You were scared.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Yeah, but you wouldn't have been.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That's not true.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: Well, I mean, you would've been scared, but… You would've done the right thing anyway. And I want to be like that. I don't… I don't want to be a loser.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You're not a loser.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: When I saw you hold her and the look on your face, it was the most beautiful thing I've ever seen. And that's when I realized… I can't.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Becca.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: My life, it's always been about pain, and anger, and disappointment. Never about love. And that's when I realized, you know, it could be. And I can't give that away.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Becca, don't do this. Uh… what you're feeling is natural. But you're filled with hormones, and emotion, and fear, and… you just can't make a huge decision like this right now. You have to give it some time.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: I am… I'm so sorry.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It's a decision that changes everything. Changes the rest of your life.

utterance.speaker: Becca
utterance.content: I hope so.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It's really not the greatest time for gloating.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There's more than one baby in the sea. The world is full of teenage boys riding bareback.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No. I'm done. I can't go through that again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're quitting. Just like you quit IVF.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yeah, just like that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There, you just did it again. It's too bad. You would've made a great mother.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You son of a bitch. When I was getting a baby, you told me I'd suck as a mother. Now that I've lost it, you tell me I'd be great as a mother. Why do you need to negate everything?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good night.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Good night.
